Member nations will have to agree, but Ms. Johansson said after a meeting of interior ministers on Sunday that â€œan overwhelming majorityâ€ was in favor.

Seven million Ukrainians are expected to be displaced as a consequence of the Russian invasion.

Ukrainians can stay visa-free in the European Union for up to 90 days, and they can move freely between member nations. According to the commission, many have already left the first country they arrived in and headed to countries with big Ukrainian diasporas, mainly the Czech Republic, Germany, Italy, Poland, Portugal and Spain.

Commenting on the same, Swedenâ€™s Minister for Integration, Anders Ygeman, said the directive is not a â€œmagic wandâ€ since it is voluntary. â€œI think to tackle this kind of situation we need binding rules in the EUâ€¦ solidarity that is bound by real decisions,â€ he added.



The never-used-before mechanism was adopted following the 2001 wars in Yugoslavia and Kosovo. The directive extends temporary and immediate protection to people from non-EU countries who have been forced to leave their country due to armed conflict, violation of their human rights, and endemic violence. The directive strikes a balance between member states by allocating refugees according to statesâ€™ accommodation capacities.



Once the mechanism is activated, all EU member states, except Denmark and Ireland, are obligated to receive the displaced people and fulfil certain obligations, including the issuance of residence permits to those granted temporary protection, which can be extended for up to three years.



Reportedly, the activation of the â€˜temporary protection directiveâ€™ will be proposed during the March 3 meeting of the EU member statesâ€™ interior and justice ministers.



According to the United Nations, more than 500,000 people have fled Ukraine and sought refuge in neighbouring countries such as Poland, Hungary, Moldova, Romania, and Slovakia. Russia has been expelled from the 2022 World Cup and its teams suspended from all international football competitions â€œuntil further noticeâ€ after its invasion of Ukraine, FIFA announced in a joint statement with UEFA on Monday. The menâ€™s team had been due to play in qualifying play-offs in March for the World Cup in Qatar later this year, while its womenâ€™s side had qualified for the European Championship in England, to be held in July.

The International Olympic Committee (IOC) recommends that Russian and Belarusian athletes and officials are banned from any organised international competitions.

The IOC has urged sport governing bodies not to allow Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete, with the Beijing Winter Paralympic Games starting on Friday. (BBC)

TRANSPORT

The trains are free and everyone can enter up to the maximum limit. Even so, several families were being separated as only children and women could pass. The capitalâ€™s central train station is completely packed. This comes after the Russian Defence Ministry said civilians can safely leave Kyiv.

SANCTIONS

Switzerland, a traditionally neutral country, will adopt all European Union sanctions against Russia, â€œwithout any exceptionâ€, the government announced on Monday, after the president had given this possibility as â€œvery likelyâ€.

Ignazio Cassis admitted that this is an â€œunprecedented and difficult stepâ€ that needed â€œcareful considerationâ€.

Finance Minister Ueli Maurer added that â€œthere will not be a single exceptionâ€ to European sanctions and that â€œit is essentialâ€ to maintain the integrity of the Swiss financial centre.

NETFIX AND SPOTIFY

Some Netflix and Spotify members in Russia say they are having trouble paying their subscription fees.

As SkyNews reports, some service users say they are receiving error messages related to their bank cards, especially from banks such as Sberbank, Tinkoff and Alfa-Bank.

It is possible that these difficulties are related to the exclusion of these banks from the SWIFT financial system but, for the moment, none of the companies has commented on the situation.

RUSSIAN BANKING

All Russian banks will have their assets frozen within days, UK Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said Monday, as part of plans to ramp up economic sanctions. â€œWe will bring in a full asset freeze on all Russian banks in days, looking to coordinate with our allies,â€ Truss told parliament, saying it was designed to prevent the Kremlin funding its invasion of Ukraine. (AFP)

Russia has a system that can replace the SWIFT global payments system internally, the governor of the countryâ€™s central bank says.Elvira Nabiullina added that all banks in Russia will fulfil their obligations and all funds on their accounts are secured.
